questions.text: Which surgical procedure should a 21-year-old boxer avoid to maintain optimal visual health? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RK

 

  • For a 21-year-old boxer who needs to maintain optimal visual health, understanding the differences between various refractive surgeries is crucial. 

 

Involves making radial cuts in the cornea to change its shape and correct refractive errors. It's not recommended for boxers because it weakens the structural integrity of the eye, making it more vulnerable to trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PRK (Photorefractive Keratectomy): This surgery involves removing the surface layer of the cornea to reshape it with a laser. It is safer than RK for athletes because it does not involve creating a flap, which could dislocate upon impact, though recovery can be slower.

 

Option C. LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis): LASIK surgery also reshapes the cornea but through creating a thin flap in the outer layer. While popular due to quick recovery times and immediate results, the flap might pose a risk in contact sports, as it could dislodge or move from direct impact.

 

Option D. SMILE (Small Incision Lenticule Extraction): The newest form of laser eye surgery, SMILE involves making a small, lenticule-shaped cut inside the cornea to reshape it without creating a flap. It offers a potentially safer option for athletes as it maintains more of the cornea's structural integrity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For a boxer, avoiding procedures that compromise the cornea's physical integrity is crucial due to the high risk of impacts to the face. Among these options, RK and potentially LASIK present higher risks. SMILE or PRK might be safer alternatives, providing effective vision correction with a reduced risk of severe complications from physical trauma.

questions.text: What is the treatment of ptosis caused by Horner's syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fasanella servat operation

 

  • The affected muscle in Horner’s syndrome is Muller's muscle, a sympathetic muscle present in the eyelid responsible for upper eyelid retraction during sympathetic stimulation. 
  • In Fasanella servat surgery, the muller’s muscle is shortened and strengthened. 
    In the other two options, levator resection and frontalis sling surgery, Muller's muscle remains intact. 
  • Thus, if asked specifically for Horner’s syndrome, even if the grade of ptosis is not mentioned, Fasanella servat operation would be the better choice to answer.
  • Here the examiner is testing your knowledge about the pathogenesis of Horner’s syndrome and the involvement of Muller's muscle. 
  • Fasanella servat operation is done for mild ptosis (< 2 mm) caused by Horner's syndrome.

 

 

Horner's syndrome is a oculosympathetic syndrome characterized by a specific set of symptoms that typically occur on one side of the face and include:

 

  1. Ptosis: Ptosis occurs because the sympathetic nerves that control the Muller’s muscle, a modification of Levator Palpebrae Superioris, involved in elevation of the eyelid are affected.
  2. Miosis:  Dissenervation of the dilator papillae (supplied by the sympathetic system) leads to miosis.
  3. Anhidrosis: This refers to a decreased ability to sweat on the affected side of the face.
  4. Pseudo-enophthalmos
  5. Hyperemia – due to disenervation of vasomotor fibers.

 

 

Other options

 

Option A. Levator resection: Used for moderate to severe ptosis, not typically indicated for the mild ptosis seen in Horner's syndrome.

 

Option B. Frontalis sling operation: Reserved for severe ptosis with poor or no levator function, which is not typical in Horner's syndrome where levator function is usually preserved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Fasanella-Servat operation is the appropriate surgical treatment for mild ptosis caused by Horner's syndrome, characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to sympathetic nerve disruption.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of 3rd nerve palsy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction limitation

 

This is not a feature of third nerve palsy. Abduction of the eye is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve. Limitation in abduction is indicative of sixth nerve palsy, not third nerve palsy. In third nerve palsy, there would be a limitation of adduction (movement of the eye towards the nose) instead.

 

Other Options:

 

Third nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve palsy) presents with several characteristic features due to the loss of function of the muscles it innervates:

 

Option A. Pupil dilatation: The third cranial nerve carries parasympathetic fibers responsible for pupil constriction. Damage to this nerve results in unopposed sympathetic stimulation, leading to pupil dilatation (mydriasis).

 

Option B. Ptosis: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle, responsible for elevating the eyelid, is innervated by the third cranial nerve. Damage to this nerve causes ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

 

Option C. Down and out eye: The unopposed action of the lateral rectus (innervated by the sixth cranial nerve) and the superior oblique (innervated by the fourth cranial nerve) results in the characteristic "down and out" position of the affected eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Third nerve palsy presents with pupil dilatation, ptosis, and a down and out eye. Abduction limitation is not a feature of third nerve palsy; it is seen in sixth nerve palsy.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. Fundus picture of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hard exudate, Diabetes mellitus

 

The given image shows small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with discrete margins that are suggestive of hard exudates, seen in diabetic macular edema.

 

 

COTTON WOOL SPOT vs HARD EXUDATE

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy

 

 

Hypertensive retinopathy

 

 

Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) – Fundoscopy reveals massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins. Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft exudate, Hypertension: Soft exudates, also known as cotton wool spots, are whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins.

 

They occur around infarcted areas and result from swelling of nerve fiber layer axons.

 

Associated with hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

 

Option C. Flame-shaped hemorrhages, Hypertension: Flame-shaped hemorrhages are superficial retinal hemorrhages that occur due to disruption of the capillaries in the retinal nerve fiber layer.

 

They are seen in diabetic retinopathy, non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion, traumatic retinopathy, Eale's disease, hypertensive retinopathy, and anemic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterized by massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins.

 

Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

Soft exudates can be seen in CRVO but are not the primary finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hard exudates are characteristic findings in diabetic retinopathy, indicating chronic localized edema and composed of leaked lipoproteins and lipid-filled macrophages. They present as small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with distinct margins in the retina.

questions.text: The Koeppe nodules is seen in: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iris

 

Iris nodules are seen in both, granulomatous and non-granulomatous anterior uveitis.

 

They are of 2 types - based on location:

 

1. Koeppes’s nodules: present at pupillary margin on the iris, and may be the site of posterior synechiae formation. seen in both, granulomatous and non-granulomatous anterior uveitis

 

2. Busacca’s nodules: present near the collarette in the body of iris. They are larger and less common, seen in granulomatous uveitis.

 

Other iris signs seen in anterior uveitis:

 

  • Edematous iris with muddy color
  • Posterior synechiae: adhesions between anterior surface of lens and posterior surface of iris
  • Adhesions around 360° of pupillary margin is called ring or annular synechiae (also called seclusio pupillae).

It results in ‘iris bombe’ formation (increased IOP due to collection of aqueous behind iris).

Iris bombe (Total posterior synechiae) also results in funnel shaped anterior chamber (deepest at centre and shallow in the periphery).

 

Findings of granulomatous uveitis:

 

  • Deposition of large Mutton fat Keratic precipitates on the back of the cornea: Large, fluffy precipitates made of macrophages and epithelioid cells having waxy or greasy appearance.
  • Absent aqueous flare.
  • Busacca nodules

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sclera: Koeppe nodules are not found in the sclera. The sclera may exhibit other signs of inflammation such as scleritis, but it does not develop Koeppe nodules.

 

Option C. Conjunctiva: The conjunctiva can show signs of inflammation such as conjunctivitis, but it does not develop Koeppe nodules.

 

Option D. Cornea: The cornea can exhibit deposits known as keratic precipitates in cases of uveitis, particularly granulomatous uveitis, but it does not develop Koeppe nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Koeppe nodules are located at the pupillary margin of the iris and are associated with both granulomatous and non-granulomatous anterior uveitis.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient who underwent perimetry had the following visual field defect. What is the site of the lesion?(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

 

The image given above shows a bitemporal hemianopsia visual field defect, caused due to a lesion at the optic chiasma.

 

VISUAL PATHWAY - Eye (Retina) → Optic Nerve → Optic Chiasm → Optic Tract → Lateral Geniculate Nucleus → Optic Radiation → Visual Cortex

 

  1. Eye (Retina): Light enters the eye and is captured by photoreceptor cells in the retina.
  2. Optic Nerve: The photoreceptor cells in the retina send signals via the optic nerve to the brain.
  3. Optic Chiasm: The optic nerve fibers from each eye cross over at the optic chiasm.
  4. Optic Tract: The fibers continue along the optic tract, which carries visual information from each eye to the brain.
  5. Lateral Geniculate Nucleus: The optic tract fibers terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.
  6. Optic Radiation: From the lateral geniculate nucleus, the visual information is transmitted via the optic radiation fibers to the visual cortex in the occipital lobe of the brain.
  7. Visual Cortex: The visual cortex processes the visual information to create the perception of vision.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Optic tract: A lesion here would result in a homonymous hemianopsia, where the same side of the visual field is lost in both eyes.

 

Option C. Optic radiations: A lesion in the optic radiations can cause a quadrant anopsia, affecting a specific quarter of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Occipital cortex: A lesion here could also cause homonymous hemianopsia, often with macular sparing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitemporal hemianopsia, characterized by loss of the outer visual fields in both eyes, is typically caused by a lesion at the optic chiasma.

questions.text: Which of the following triad is seen after an acute attack of angle-closure glaucoma? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vogt's triad

 

  • Vogt's triad is seen after an acute attack of primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • It includes glaukomflecken, patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreactive pupil.
  • Glaukomflecken is used to describe an anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity due to necrosis of lens cortical fibers.
  • The mid-dilated pupil is attributed to sphincter atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Virchow triad is used to describe the abnormalities that result in thrombosis. It includes endothelial injury, abnormal blood flow, and hypercoagulability of the blood.

 

Option C. Hutchinson triad is used to describe manifestations of congenital syphilis. It includes interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson teeth, and eighth nerve deafness. Hutchinson teeth are screw-driver or peg shaped small incisors.

 

Option D. Gaucher's triad is not a named triad. Hypertonia, strabismus, and stridor usually point to a diagnosis of type 2 Gaucher's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vogt's triad in a patient with a history of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma can aid in rapid diagnosis and management of this potentially vision-threatening condition. It underscores the importance of timely intervention to preserve ocular health and prevent irreversible complications.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of angle-closure glaucoma has been diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which of the following drugs have to be avoided in this patient? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amitriptyline

 

  • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that is known to have marked anticholinergic activity.
  • TCAs have high affinity for muscarinic acetylcholine (M type) receptors, causing the subsequent blockade of these receptors.
  • Blocking of these receptors can result in decreased outflow of aqueous humour, leading to an increase in intraocular pressure.
  • This effect can exacerbate pre-existing angle-closure type glaucoma, which is already characterized by impaired drainage of aqueous humour.
  • Therefore, amitriptyline is a drug to be avoided in patients with angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B and D: Sertraline and Fluvoxamine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors with no activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors and therefore have no effect on the outflow of aqueous humor and thereby, on the intraocular pressure.

 

Option C: Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that is a serotonin-norephedrine reuptake inhibitor with the ability to precipitate angle-closure glaucoma by itself; however, due to lack of any activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors, it does not increase the intraocular pressure to the extent that Amitriptyline does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with angle-closure glaucoma, medications with anticholinergic properties, such as Amitriptyline, should be avoided due to their potential to increase intraocular pressure and exacerbate the condition.

questions.text: Which visual field defect is shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enlarged blind spots

 

The correct answer is Enlarged blind spots. The image shows a significant enlargement of the physiological blind spot, which is a hallmark of conditions such as papilledema. Papilledema is a condition characterized by optic disc swelling due to increased intracranial pressure. This swelling leads to an enlarged blind spot-on visual field testing, which is prominently seen in the images provided.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Altitudinal field defects: These defects present as a loss of vision above or below the horizontal line, resembling a band-like defect across the visual field. This type of defect is commonly seen in conditions like ischemic optic neuropathy or branch retinal artery or vein occlusion.

 

 

Option C. Arcuate field defects: Arcuate defects appear as arc-shaped visual losses that extend from the blind spot and follow the nerve fiber layer pattern. This type of defect is typically seen in glaucoma and other optic neuropathies.

 

 

Option D. Roennes nasal step: This defect is characterized by a step-like pattern near the nasal visual field, commonly seen in glaucoma. It occurs due to the asymmetry between the superior and inferior nerve fiber bundles

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enlarged blind spots on visual field testing are indicative of conditions like papilledema, where optic disc swelling leads to an increased physiological blind spot

choices.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter
Fluorescein dye - visualised under green filter

questions.text: What is the dye and filter used as seen in the image?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

 

he most likely correct combination for fluorescein dye visualization is Fluorescein dye - visualized under cobalt blue filter. Fluorescein is a yellow dye that, when applied to the eye, emits a bright green fluorescence when illuminated with blue light from a cobalt blue filter. It's commonly used in ophthalmology to detect corneal abrasions, ulcers, or foreign bodies and to assess contact lens fit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a green filter: Lissamine Green is a dye that stains devitalized cells and mucous filaments and is used to visualize damage to the conjunctiva and cornea, particularly in dry eye syndrome. It is typically observed under white light, not a green filter, so this combination is not standard.

 

Option C. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a cobalt blue filter: This is not the standard practice for visualizing Lissamine Green dye. This dye is usually observed under white light, as the cobalt blue filter is specifically used to excite fluorescence from fluorescein dye.

 

Option D. Fluorescein dye - visualized under a green filter: Fluorescein dye is usually visualized under a blue light, not a green filter. When fluorescein is viewed under a green filter, the fluorescence is typically not visible because the green filter would block the green fluorescence emitted by the fluorescein dye.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In ophthalmology, different dyes and filters are used to aid in the diagnosis of various conditions. Fluorescein dye is visualized using a cobalt blue filter, which causes it to fluoresce and highlights areas of corneal compromise. It is crucial to use the appropriate filter for each dye to accurately diagnose and assess ocular surface disorders.

questions.text: Extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line is called as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Distichiasis

 

Distichiasis refers to the additional row of eyelashes behind the grey line. It may happen as a result of inherited or acquired factors.

 

The cornea may become irritated by these lashes. The treatment involves separating the lids and applying cryotherapy to the hair follicles' bases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichiasis: Refers to the misdirection of eyelashes that grow inward towards the eye, causing irritation and potential damage to the cornea. The lid margin remains in its normal position.

 

Option C. Tylosis: Refers to the thickening of the tarsal plate, often associated with chronic inflammation and lid margin disease, but not related to an extra row of eyelashes.

 

Option D. Madarosis: Refers to the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows, which can be due to various causes including trauma, systemic diseases, and dermatologic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distichiasis is the condition where an extra row of eyelashes grows behind the normal lash line, often leading to corneal irritation and requiring treatment such as cryotherapy or electrolysis to prevent complications.

questions.text:
Which of these options are considered direct gonioscopes?(INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Goldmann
  2. Richardson
  3. Zeis
  4. Koeppe
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

Richardson and Koeppe are direct gonioscopes.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPY - It is performed with a steep convex lens which permits light from the angle to exit the eye closer to the perpendicular at the lens - air interface. These lenses are used with an operating microscope.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples –

 

  • Koeppe goniolens
  • Richardson- Shaffer's lens
  • Sieback goniolens
  • Worth goniolens
  • Swan Jacob's lens
  • Huskins barkan's lens

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPY - uses mirrors or prism to overcome the problem of total internal reflection. Moreover, it uses the slit lamp's illumination and magnification system to its advantage.

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples –

 

  • Goldmann Gonioprism
  • Zeis Gonioprism
  • Tokel Gonioprism

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct gonioscopes like Richardson and Koeppe provide a detailed and direct view of the anterior chamber angle, which is valuable in diagnostic and certain therapeutic procedures.

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

1-b: Colour vision - Ishihara chart:

 

Colour vision is tested with Ishihara plates, which is a pseudoisochromatic chart. There are patterns of coloured and grey dots that reveal one pattern to persons with normal colour vision and another to those with the colour deficiency.

 

The below image shows a representative plate of the Ishihara chart.

 

 

Limitation of ischihara chart: Ischihara chart is useful as a screening tool for colour blindness. It mainly tests for red-green blindness.

 

In order to check blue-yellow blindness other tests such as 100 Hue Test are required.

 

2-a: Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer:

 

An applanation tonometer is used to measure the intraocular pressure. It is based on the Imbert-Fick law, which states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A).

 

P = W/A

 

The following is an image of the applanation tonometer:

 

 

There are two types of applanation tonometers:

 

(1) In which the surface area of the prism is constant – Eg

 

  1. Goldmann Applanation Tonometer (GAT):
    • The Goldmann tonometer is one of the most widely used and considered the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It consists of a prism that is gently applied to the anesthetized cornea, flattening a small area.
    • The amount of force required to flatten the cornea is directly related to intraocular pressure.
  2. Perkins Applanation Tonometer:
    • The Perkins tonometer is a handheld, portable device used for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It is similar in principle to the Goldmann tonometer but is more compact and easier to transport.
  3. Tono-Pen (Reichert Tonometer):
    • The Tono-Pen is a handheld electronic applanation tonometer.
    • It works by measuring the force required to flatten the cornea, and the reading is displayed electronically.
    • It is often used in clinical settings due to its ease of use and portability.

 

(2) Tonometer with constant pressure and variable area – eg. MALAKOFF’S Tonometer.

 

3-d: Peripheral vision - Perimetry:

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic procedure used to chart the boundaries of a person's visual field. There are two main types of perimetry: kinetic and static perimetry. Kinetic perimetry involves moving a target with a specific luminance from a non-seeing area in the periphery towards the center until the person perceives it. In contrast, static perimetry involves presenting a stationary stimulus and adjusting its intensity until the person either reaches a threshold of detection or can no longer detect it. One type of static perimetry is tangent screen perimetry, which tests the central 30 degrees field at 1 meter and evaluates a person's central vision.

 

Examples of Kinetic Perimetry – Goldmann perimetry and Bjerrum Perimetry

 

Examples of Static Perimetry – Static Automated perimetry – Humphrey Visual Field analyser and Octopus Visual field analyser.

 

4-c: Central vision - Tangent screen test:

 

The tangent screen test is a specific method used to assess central visual field up to 30 degrees from fixation. It involves using a black screen and white or colored targets to determine the sensitivity of central vision, particularly useful in detecting central visual field defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colour vision - Ishihara chart
  • Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer
  • Peripheral vision - Perimetry
  • Central vision - Tangent screen test

questions.text: What is anisometropia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Difference in refractive error

 

Anisometropia refers to a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive error (i.e., the focusing power) between the two eyes. This difference can cause each eye to focus differently, leading to difficulties in binocular vision and sometimes resulting in amblyopia (lazy eye) if one eye is significantly more affected than the other.

 

  1. ANISOMETROPIA: Difference between Refractive Error of two eyes
  2. ANISEIKONIA: Difference between Image size in two eyes
  3. ANISOCORIA: Difference between Pupil size of two eyes
  4. ANISOPIA: Difference between vision of two eyes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Difference in color of iris: Incorrect. This condition is called heterochromia, not anisometropia. Heterochromia refers to a difference in coloration, typically of the iris.

 

Option C. Difference in axial length: Incorrect. While differences in axial length can contribute to anisometropia, the term itself specifically refers to differences in refractive error, not just axial length.

 

Option D. Difference in visual acuity: Incorrect. Although anisometropia can lead to differences in visual acuity between the two eyes, the term specifically refers to the difference in refractive error, not visual acuity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropia is defined as a difference in the refractive error between the two eyes, which can lead to difficulties in binocular vision and potentially cause amblyopia in the more affected eye.

questions.text: Oculus Dexter refers to: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right Eye

 

Oculus Dexter (OD) is the Latin medical term used to specifically designate the right eye in ophthalmological documentation. This terminology is part of the standard nomenclature in ophthalmic practice and is used in prescriptions, medical records, and clinical communications. The counterpart term for the left eye is Oculus Sinister (OS), while Oculus Uterque (OU) refers to both eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left Eye: This is incorrect as left eye is designated as Oculus Sinister (OS), not Oculus Dexter. This is a fundamental distinction in ophthalmic terminology that prevents confusion in patient management.

 

Option C. Both Eyes: This is incorrect because both eyes are referred to as Oculus Uterque (OU). Oculus Dexter specifically refers to only the right eye, not both eyes simultaneously.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect because Oculus Dexter does indeed have a specific meaning in ophthalmic terminology, which is the right eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculus Dexter (OD) refers specifically to the right eye in ophthalmological terminology, forming part of the essential Latin abbreviations used in clinical documentation alongside OS (left eye) and OU (both eyes).

questions.text: A malnourished child from a poor socioeconomic background, living in overcrowded and unsanitary conditions, presents with a nodule around the limbus and redness of the surrounding conjunctiva in his left eye. The child also has axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phlyctenular Conjunctivitis

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests phlyctenular conjunctivitis. This condition is characterized by a nodular lesion (phlycten) occurring at the limbus with surrounding hyperemia. It typically affects children living in poor hygienic conditions who are undernourished. The unilateral presentation is also characteristic, as phlyctenular conjunctivitis is usually unilateral, in contrast to conditions like vernal keratoconjunctivitis which are bilateral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foreign Body Granuloma: This is incorrect because foreign body granulomas typically have a history of trauma or foreign body entry. They also don't correlate with the socioeconomic factors and malnutrition mentioned in the case. Foreign body granulomas are common following squint surgery or inadequately scraped chalazion.

 

Option C. Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis: This is incorrect because vernal keratoconjunctivitis is typically bilateral, seasonal (worse in warm weather), and characterized by severe itching, papillary hypertrophy arranged in a "cobblestone" pattern, and ropy discharge. It's not specifically associated with poor socioeconomic conditions or malnutrition.

 

Option D. Episcleritis: This is incorrect because episcleritis presents with sectoral redness without discharge, is more common in adults, and is not specifically associated with poor living conditions or malnutrition. The nodular lesion at the limbus is not a typical feature of episcleritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous microbial proteins, particularly common in malnourished children living in poor hygienic conditions, presenting as a characteristic whitish raised nodule on the bulbar conjunctiva with surrounding hyperemia

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of penetrating injury to the eye. A diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis was confirmed. Which of the following will be seen? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Panuveitis

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous pan-uveitis.
  • Usually occurs after penetrative trauma or intraocular surgery.
  • Both eyes develop panuveitis: the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye).
  • Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.
  • The most accepted theory is the allergic theory which postulates that the uveal pigment acts as an allergen and excites plastic uveitis in the sound eye.
  • Usual time of onset of sympathetic ophthalmitis – 4-8 weeks after injury.
  • Earliest symptoms in uninjured eye:
    • Difficulty in near vision (Due to loss of accommodation)
    •  Photophobia
  • Earliest sign in uninjured eye: Retrolental flare.
  • Dalen-Fuch’s nodules are seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis. These are small, yellow white spots scattered throughout the fundus. These consist of epithelioid cells and are present between retinal pigmented epithelium and Bruch’s membrane.
  • Best time for enucleation (not evisceration) of an injured eye in order to prevent sympathetic ophthalmia in uninjured eye- within 15 days.

 

   

 

Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease (VKH) and sympathetic ophthalmia (SO) are bilateral, autoimmune granulomatous intraocular inflammatory conditions with nearly identical findings on ophthalmic exam. Both can reveal serous retinal detachments, optic disc edema, vitritis, and Dalen-Fuchs nodules, but they differ in key facets such as a history of penetrating ocular injury in SO and greater systemic associations in VKH. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute anterior uveitis: Acute anterior uveitis involves inflammation limited to the anterior part of the uvea (iris and ciliary body) and does not typically follow the pattern seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis, which affects the entire uveal tract.

 

Option B. Pars planitis: Pars planitis is a form of intermediate uveitis that primarily affects the peripheral retina and pars plana. It does not encompass the entire uveal tract as in panuveitis.

 

Option D. Chronic anterior uveitis: Chronic anterior uveitis is a long-standing inflammation of the anterior uvea, typically affecting only the iris and ciliary body, not the entire uveal tract as seen in panuveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous panuveitis that occurs after penetrating eye injuries or intraocular surgeries, affecting both the injured and uninjured eyes. It involves inflammation of the entire uveal tract and is characterized by features such as Dalen-Fuch's nodules and retrolental flare in the uninjured eye.

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Giant papillary conjunctivitis

 

  • The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis is the inflammation of conjunctiva with formation of very large sized papillae.
  • Etiology - It is a localized allergic response to a physically rough or deposited surface (contact lens, prosthesis, left out nylon sutures).
  • Symptoms - Itching, stringy discharge and reduced wearing time of contact lens or prosthetic shell.
  • Signs - Papillary hypertrophy (1 mm in diameter) of the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae. Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Treatment:
    1. The offending cause should be removed. After discontinuation of contact lens or artificial eye or removal of nylon sutures, the papillae resolve over a period of one month.
    2. Disodium cromoglycate is known to relieve the symptoms and enhance the rate of resolution.
    3. Steroids are not of much use in this condition.

 

Other Options:

                                        

Option A. In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

 

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.

 

 

Option B. It is an acute catarrhal conjunctivitis associated with marked follicular hyperplasia especially of the lower fornix and lower palpebral conjunctiva. Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses.

 

The image shows follicles.

 

 

Option D. Spring catarrh is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to some exogenous allergen, such as grass pollens. It is more common during summer. Cobblestone appearance (which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva), ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen.

 

The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

 

 

Pseudogerontoxon - Pseudogerontoxon is a lesion that resembles a small segment of arcus senilis or gerontoxon and is seen in many individuals with limbal vernal or atopic keratoconjunctivitis. It is an important clinical finding because pseudogerontoxon is often times the only clinical evidence of previous allergic eye disease.

 

 

Shield Ulcer- Localized oval or pentagonal lesion in upper cornea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is characterized by the presence of large papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, often due to a localized allergic response to contact lenses or other foreign bodies.

choices.text: Both iris details and pupil margins are seen.
Both iris details and pupil margins are not seen.

questions.text: In the case of macular corneal opacity, which of the following is true? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pupil margins are seen

 

Explanation: 


In macular corneal opacity, the iris details are not visible through the opacity, but the pupil margin can be easily seen. This is a key distinguishing feature of macular opacity compared to other types of corneal opacities. Macular opacity involves significant stromal injury but affects less than half the depth of the stroma. The opacity is easily visible but allows some visualization of deeper structures like pupillary margins.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Iris details are seen: This is incorrect. In macular opacity, the texture and details of the iris are obscured by the opacity.

 

Option C. Both iris details and pupil margins are seen: This is incorrect and better describes nebular opacity, which is the mildest form where both iris details and pupil margins are visible.

 

Option D. Both iris details and pupil margins are not seen: This is incorrect and describes leucomatous opacity, which is the densest form where neither iris details nor pupil margins are visible.

 

Educational Objective: 


Macular corneal opacity, pupil margins are visible while iris details cannot be seen - this is a key diagnostic feature that helps differentiate it from other types of corneal opacities.

choices.text: Cobalt blue with trypan blue for corneal ulcer
Cobalt green with Rose Bengal stain for corneal opacity
Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer
Cobalt blue with lissamine green for corneal abrasion

questions.text: Which of the following accurately pairs the  diagnostic stain with the corneal condition it indicates? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer

 

This is the correct match. Fluorescein, when used with a cobalt blue light, stains areas of corneal epithelial loss, highlighting defects such as corneal ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobalt blue with trypan blue for corneal ulcer: Trypan blue is generally used in cataract surgery to stain the anterior capsule, not for diagnosing corneal ulcers.

 

Option B. Cobalt green with Rose Bengal stain for corneal opacity: Rose Bengal stain is actually used to detect damage to the eye's surface cells, particularly in cases of dry eye where these cells are more vulnerable. 

 

Option D. Cobalt blue with lissamine green for corneal abrasion: Lissamine green stains areas of cell loss or damage on the surface of the eye, such as in cases of corneal abrasion or dry eye. It’s used under white light rather than cobalt blue light.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fluorescein stain under cobalt blue light remains a standard and effective method for diagnosing corneal ulcers due to its ability to vividly highlight areas of epithelial loss.

questions.text: A biopsy was performed on a patient with a recurrent chalazion involving the upper eyelid. What is the most likely diagnosis on histopathology? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sebaceous Cell Carcinoma

 

Sebaceous cell carcinoma can often masquerade as a recurrent chalazion, making it a diagnostic challenge. It arises from the meibomian glands and frequently involves the upper eyelid. This malignancy typically presents initially as a nodule that may be mistaken for a chalazion, more frequently on the upper eyelid. Recurrent chalazion that doesn't respond to conventional treatment should raise suspicion for this malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma: While this is the most common malignant tumor of the eyelids (90% of eyelid malignancies), it typically presents as a noduloulcerative lesion with pearly rolled margins (rodent ulcer). It most commonly affects the lower eyelid (50%) followed by medial canthus, and doesn't typically mimic a chalazion.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma: This presents as a scaly, erythematous plaque with elevated and indurated margins or occasionally as nodular/polypoidal growth. It commonly arises from the lid margin, not from the meibomian glands, and doesn't typically resemble a chalazion.

 

Option D. Malignant Melanoma: This rare eyelid tumor (less than 1% of eyelid lesions) presents as a pigmented, well-defined lesion that later becomes elevated, or as a nodular growth. It doesn't typically mimic a chalazion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Recurrent chalazia, especially in older patients, should raise suspicion for sebaceous cell carcinoma, warranting histopathological examination to avoid misdiagnosis of this potentially lethal malignancy.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankyloblepharon

 

Ankyloblepharon is a condition where the upper and lower eyelids become attached to each other. This can happen as a congenital anomaly or due to adhesions that form during the healing process of traumatic wounds, ulcers, or chemical burns affecting the eyelid margins. Treatment involves removing the adhesions between the eyelid margins. In cases where adhesions extend to the angles, epithelial grafts should be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva in which the eyelids become adherent to the eyeball.

 

The image given below shows symblepharon.

 

 

Option C: Congenital blepharophimosis is a condition in which the extent of the palpebral fissure is decreased. It can be congenital or acquired and is due to a vertical skin fold at the lateral canthus. No treatment is required. In some cases, canthoplasty is done.

 

 

Option D: Congenital ptosis is a condition present since birth and is characterized by drooping of one or both upper eyelids due to developmental defects or weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle. The affected individuals may also have lid lag on downward gaze. The most common treatment for congenital ptosis is surgical correction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankyloblepharon involves the fusion of the eyelid margins, which can be congenital or acquired, and requires surgical intervention to correct the adhesion and restore normal eyelid function and appearance.

questions.text: Where is Scarpa's Staphyloma typically observed? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myopia

 

Posterior staphyloma, also referred to as Scarpa's staphyloma, is typically observed in pathological myopia. It occurs due to ectasia (outward bulging) of the sclera at the posterior pole and appears as an excavation with blood vessels bending backward over its margins. This is a characteristic finding in high/pathological myopia, where the axial length increases abnormally, causing stretching and thinning of the ocular coats at the posterior pole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal Detachment: This is incorrect. While retinal detachment can occur as a complication of pathological myopia and may coexist with posterior staphyloma, the staphyloma itself is not a characteristic finding of primary retinal detachment. Retinal detachment is characterized by separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium.

 

Option C. Glaucoma: This is incorrect. Glaucoma is characterized by optic disc cupping and not posterior staphyloma. The excavation in glaucoma involves the optic nerve head rather than the entire posterior pole as seen in staphyloma. Though myopic patients may have increased risk for glaucoma, posterior staphyloma is primarily associated with pathological myopia.

 

Option D. Iridocyclitis: This is incorrect. Iridocyclitis (anterior uveitis) primarily affects the iris and ciliary body in the anterior segment of the eye. Posterior staphyloma occurs in the posterior segment and is not a feature of inflammatory conditions of the anterior uvea. Iridocyclitis typically presents with pain, photophobia, and circumcorneal injection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior staphyloma is a defining feature of pathological myopia resulting from weakening and outward bulging of the posterior sclera due to excessive axial elongation, leading to characteristic fundus changes and increased risk for macular pathology.

questions.text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Moraxella lacunata

 

  • Moraxella species are gram-negative diplococci that can cause angular conjunctivitis.
  • Angular conjunctivitis is characterized by inflammation of the inner and outer canthi, skin excoriation, and a collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.
  • Moraxella axenfeld, Moraxella lacunata, and Moraxella catarrhalis are common causes of angular conjunctivitis, while Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause.
  • The source of infection is the nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis.
  • The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs.
  • Oxytetracycline is the preferred treatment for angular conjunctivitis, with a duration of 10 to 14 days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haemophilus influenzae: While this organism can cause bacterial conjunctivitis, it is not specifically associated with angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus type 32: Adenoviruses can cause viral conjunctivitis, including epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, but they are not the typical cause of angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Coxsackie B virus: This virus can cause viral infections including conjunctivitis, but it is not the usual causative agent for angular conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary causative organism of angular conjunctivitis is Moraxella lacunata, which is a gram-negative diplococci. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs, and is characterized by inflammation of the canthi and a dirty-white, foamy discharge. The preferred treatment is oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days.

questions.text: A patient working in an iron factory presents with visual disturbance and is found to have iron deposits in the eye. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this ocular finding?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Siderosis bulbi

 

Siderosis bulbi is the condition where iron gets deposited in the eye due to the entry of an iron foreign body. This is commonly seen in industrial settings where iron is frequently used.

 

Ocular changes includes heterochromia (change in the color of the iris), iron deposits in the lens, uvea, and retina, leading to conditions like uveitis, retinitis, and even optic atrophy. These changes can result in severe visual impairment and blindness.

 

The condition can present immediately after the injury or even years later.

 

Severe cases can lead to phthisis bulbi, a condition where the eye becomes shrunken and non-functional.

 

The investigation of choice for detecting an iron foreign body is a CT scan or a B-scan ultrasound, as MRI is contraindicated due to the magnetic nature of iron.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chalcosis: This condition is caused by copper deposition in the eye. It is seen in cases involving copper foreign bodies.

 

Option C. Kayser-Fleischer ring: This is a brownish ring around the cornea seen in Wilson's disease, a condition involving copper metabolism disorder.

 

Option D. Retinitis pigmentosa: This is a genetic disorder causing pigmentary dystrophy of the retina. It does not involve iron deposits and is unrelated to the occupational exposure described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Siderosis bulbi is caused by iron deposits in the eye, commonly seen in patients with a history of iron foreign body exposure, leading to significant ocular changes and potential blindness.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not accurate concerning a chalazion? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Associated with Severe Pain

 

A chalazion is characterized by being painless rather than painful. Chalazion symptoms include "painless swelling in the eyelid, gradually increasing in size." It is specifically described as a "chronic non-infective (non-suppurative) lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland" that develops without significant pain, which contrasts with painful conditions like hordeolum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Onset: Correct statement. Chalazion is defined as a "chronic non-infective lipogranulomatous inflammation" that develops gradually with "painless swelling in the eyelid, gradually increasing in size."

 

Option B. Involvement of the Meibomian Gland: Correct statement. Chalazion is specifically described as a "chronic non-infective (non-suppurative) lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland."

 

Option D. Characterized by Granulomatous Inflammation: Correct statement. A chalazion is definitively a "lipogranulomatous inflammation."

 

Contrast with painful lid conditions: Unlike chalazion, conditions like hordeolum externum (stye) and hordeolum internum are characterized by "acute pain associated with swelling of the lid." In hordeolum internum, the pain is even described as "more intense, due to the swelling being embedded deeply in the dense fibrous tissue."

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chalazion is a painless, chronic, lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland, which distinguishes it from painful acute lid conditions like hordeolum.

questions.text: What is the action of the superior oblique muscle? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion, abduction, depression

 

  • The superior oblique muscle is responsible for three actions: intorsion, depression, and abduction.
  • Each eye has six extraocular muscles: four recti muscles and two oblique muscles.
  • The recti muscles are the superior, inferior, medial, and lateral rectus.
  • The superior oblique muscle originates from the apex of the orbit, turns around the trochlea, and inserts into the sclera behind the equator.
  • The tendon's oblique direction gives it a rotator effect, resulting in intorsion, as well as depression and abduction.
  • These muscles control both unilateral and binocular movements of the eye.
  • Unilateral eye movements are called Ductions.
  • Bilateral eye movements are called Versions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: After cataract surgery, a patient developed vision problems. OCT finding is shown below. This is associated with which syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irvine-Gass syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Irvine-Gass syndrome, is a well-known complication in which cystoid macular edema (CME occurs 4 to 6 weeks after cataract surgery. It is characterized by the development of cystoid spaces in the macula, which appear as hyporeflective spaces on Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT).

 

This syndrome is commonly associated with:

 

  • Post-cataract surgery patients, particularly those with pre-existing conditions like diabetes or uveitis or glaucoma patients on PG analogues.
  • Inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandins and cytokines are released post-surgery, leading to increased vascular permeability and leakage of fluid into the macular layers.
  • Fluorescein angiography (FFA) typically shows a petalloid pattern of hyperfluorescence due to leakage from perifoveal capillaries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR):

 

  • CSR is characterized by serous detachment of the neurosensory retina at the macula due to increased choroidal permeability.
  • OCT shows serous elevation of the retina without cystic spaces, unlike the cystoid spaces in CME.
  • FFA typically shows an inkblot or smokestack pattern.

 

 

Option B. Elschnig Pearls:

 

  • These are seen in cases of posterior capsular opacification (PCO), which can occur months to years after cataract surgery.
  • This condition is seen on the posterior capsule of the lens bag and not on Retina
  • Patients complain of gradual, painless vision deterioration, unlike the acute onset of CME.

 

Option D. Posner-Schlossman Syndrome:

 

  • Also known as glaucomatocyclitic crisis, it is an inflammatory condition that presents with elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) and mild anterior uveitis.
  • It does not cause cystoid macular edema (CME) or changes seen in Irvine-Gass syndrome.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irvine-Gass syndrome (cystoid macular edema) is a complication of cataract surgery that presents 4 to 6 weeks postoperatively. It is best diagnosed using OCT and treated with NSAIDs or steroids.

questions.text: During an ophthalmic examination, the patient is asked to direct her gaze to her right side. During this ocular movement, the right lateral rectus muscle is being used. Which of the following is its yoke muscle?(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left medial rectus

 

Left medial rectus and Right lateral Rectus are yoke muscles.

 

Yoke muscle - contralaterally paired extraocular muscles that works synergistically to direct the gaze in a given direction. For example, in directing the gaze to the right, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus operate together as yoke muscles.

 

Examples:

 

  • Right MR and Left LR
  • Right LR and Left MR
  • Right SO and Left IR
  • Right IO and Left SR
  • Right SR and Left IO
  • Right IR and Left SO

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left superior oblique: This muscle is responsible for intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye. It is not the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus.

 

Option C. Right medial rectus: This muscle is responsible for adduction of the right eye, not synergistic with the right lateral rectus during rightward gaze.

 

Option D. Left lateral rectus: This muscle is responsible for abduction of the left eye and would work with the right medial rectus for leftward gaze, not rightward gaze.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yoke muscles are pairs of extraocular muscles from opposite eyes that work together to direct the gaze in a specific direction. For rightward gaze, the yoke muscles are the right lateral rectus and the left medial rectus.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with distant visual acuity of 6/18, which improved on pin-hole testing. He gives history of not needing glasses for near vision now. On ocular examination findings as shown in image were seen. Patient has which of the following refractory error. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Index Myopia

 

Given the patient's age and the description of the symptoms, the most likely refractive error in this case is Index Myopia. This occurs when nuclear sclerosis starts in the crystalline lens, resulting in change in the density and hence the refractive index of the lens. This causes light rays to focus in front of the retina, leading to blurred distant vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axial Myopia: Axial myopia is a common form of myopia and is usually a stable condition that doesn't suddenly appear in old age.

 

Option B. Curvatural Myopia: This form of myopia is due to an increased curvature of the cornea or lens, which makes the eye's focusing power too strong. This also results in the focal point being in front of the retina, causing distant objects to be blurred. Like axial myopia, curvatural myopia is generally present from a younger age and does not develop suddenly in seniors.

 

Option C. Positional Myopia: This type of myopia can occur due to the displacement of the lens within the eye, which can sometimes happen with a subluxated lens. Positional myopia is not a common form of myopia and would not typically be associated with the symptom of improved near vision without the need for glasses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phenomenon of "second sight" in older adults is often associated with the development of nuclear sclerotic cataracts, which can cause a change in the refractive index of the lens, leading to index myopia. An important clinical sign is improvement in near vision in a previously hypermetropic (or presbyopic) individual, along with a decrease in distance vision that improves with pinhole testing. It's essential to recognize these signs and symptoms for the correct diagnosis and management of cataracts.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

 

  • Diagnosis based on the given image: Pseudoexfoliation syndrome (PES)
  • PES is an age-related degenerative disorder, commonly seen in women.
  • Characterized by deposition of an amorphous grey dandruff-like material on:
    • Pupillary border
    • Anterior lens surface
    • Posterior surface of iris
    • Zonules
    • Ciliary processes
  • Trabecular blockage by exfoliative material can lead to:
    • Secondary open-angle glaucoma
    • Rarely, angle-closure glaucoma
  • Other ocular symptoms may include:
    • Iris sphincter atrophy
    • Anisocoria
    • Heterochromia
  • Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.

  • Common intraocular foreign bodies:
    • Glass particles or metal chips.
  • Sites of lodgement: 
    • The anterior chamber
    • Lens
    • Posterior chamber
    • Vitreous humour
  • Consequences of lodgement: 
    • Cataract formation
    • Vitreous liquefaction
    • Retinal haemorrhages
    • Tears
    • Organic foreign bodies can cause infection.
    • Iron foreign bodies can cause siderosis.
    • Copper ones can result in chalcosis.
  • An entry wound can be identified with topical fluorescein.
  • MRI is contraindicated in metallic intraocular foreign bodies.

 

Option C.

 

Ocular trauma can be of 2 types:

  1. Closed-globe injury: can vary from simple corneal abrasions to widespread intraocular damage. A corneal abrasion highlighted with fluorescein staining is shown below.
  2. Open-globe injury: includes globe rupture or laceration.

 

 

Option D. Vossius ring is used to describe a ring-shaped pigment dispersal observed on the anterior surface of the lens due to the deposition of brown amorphous pigment granules. It is close to the constricted pupil in diameter. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, creating an impression of the iris on the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of amorphous grey dandruff-like material on various parts of the eye, leading to potential complications like secondary open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with sudden painless loss of vision. Examination reveals perception of only hand movements in the affected eye with afferent pupillary defect. On examination, his fundus was pale in color with a red spot in the center. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CRAO

 

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is an ophthalmic emergency characterized by sudden, painless loss of vision. The key clinical findings in CRAO include a marked decrease in visual acuity, often to the level of hand movements or light perception, and an afferent pupillary defect (relative afferent pupillary defect, or RAPD). On fundoscopic examination, a pale retina with a cherry red spot at the fovea is a classic finding. This red spot is due to the underlying choroidal circulation, which remains intact while the surrounding ischemic retina appears pale.

 

Key Features of CRAO:

 

  • Cherry red spot: This is a hallmark of CRAO and occurs due to the contrast between the pale, ischemic retina and the preserved circulation of the choroid at the fovea.
  • Sudden, painless vision loss: Typically, patients present with a sudden and severe decrease in vision in the affected eye.
  • Afferent pupillary defect: Indicates a significant loss of retinal ganglion cells’ function.

 

Most Common Cause:

 

  • Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis: Often at the level of the lamina cribrosa, leading to an occlusion of the central retinal artery.

 

Additional Examination Findings:

 

  • Cattle track/box car appearance: This appearance of the blood column in the retinal arteries is due to segmentation caused by sluggish blood flow.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Paracentesis: An emergency procedure to lower intraocular pressure and potentially dislodge the embolus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CRVO: Central retinal vein occlusion typically presents with sudden vision loss but is associated with a different set of fundoscopic findings, including retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and dilated, tortuous veins, rather than a pale retina with a cherry red spot.

 

Option C. Cystic edema: Usually refers to macular edema, presenting with blurred or distorted central vision, not sudden and severe vision loss.

 

Option D. Macular edema: Characterized by fluid accumulation in the macula, causing blurred vision but not typically associated with a cherry red spot or the severe vision loss seen in CRAO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differential diagnosis of cherry red spot:

 

  • CRAO
  • Trauma
  • Niemann pick disease
  • Gaucher’s disease
  • Tay sach’s disease
  • Sandhoff’s disease

choices.text: Retinal pigmentation
Pale waxy disc
Narrowing of vessels
ERG – normal

questions.text: What among the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. ERG – normal

 

ERG is abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa.

 

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a primary pigmentary retinal dystrophy predominantly affecting the rods more than the cones.
  • It is the most common hereditary fundus dystrophy, with the most common mode of inheritance being autosomal recessive.
  • In early disease, it shows reduced scotopic rod and combined responses, and photopic responses reduce with progression.
  • Eventually, the ERG becomes extinguished.
  • The characteristic visual symptom is night blindness, which may present several years before visible changes in the retina appear.
  • Dark adaptation is affected, and tubular vision may occur in advanced cases.
  • Fundus changes include bone-spicule retinal pigmentation, arteriolar attenuation, and 'waxy' disc pallor.

 

  • Visual field changes-
    • Annular or ring-shaped scotoma is a typical feature which corresponds to the degenerated equatorial zone of retina. As the disease progresses, scotoma increases anteriorly and posteriorly and ultimately only central vision is left (tubular vision). Eventually even this is also lost and the patient becomes blind.

 

  • Electrophysiological changes-

1. Electro-retinogram (ERG) is subnormal or abolished.

2. Electro-oculogram (EOG) shows absence of light peak.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Pale Waxy Disc: Optic disc pallor due to progressive degeneration.

 

Option C. Narrowing of Vessels: Attenuation of retinal arterioles due to retinal thinning and atrophy.

 

Option D.  ERG (Electroretinogram: ERG is not normal in retinitis pigmentosa. It shows abnormal findings, such as:

  • Early Disease: Reduced scotopic (rod) response and combined responses.
  • Progression: Reduced photopic (cone) responses.
  • Advanced Disease: ERG becomes extinguished or abolished

 

Educational Objective:

 

In retinitis pigmentosa, the ERG is not normal; it shows progressive abnormalities reflecting the degeneration of photoreceptor cells. Other features include retinal pigmentation, pale waxy disc, and narrowing of retinal vessels.

questions.text: Which sequence of dyes is employed for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

The optimal sequence of dyes for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining from the provided choices is as follows: Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

Fluorescein stain – it is an orange colored dye → stains the defect. Under cobalt blue light, the defect appears green.

 

Rose Bengal stain – stains the dead cells. It causes stinging, so, not very popular, and so applied the last.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended sequence of application—starting with fluorescein, followed by lissamine green, and ending with Rose Bengal—minimizes discomfort and interference between the dyes. Since Rose Bengal can be irritating, it is applied last, after the assessment with the less irritating dyes has been completed.

questions.text: Identify the condition: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oculomotor nerve palsy

 

The given image suggests a diagnosis of oculomotor nerve palsy because of the following features:

 

  • Left eye is deviating downwards and outwards.
  • Left eyelid is showing ptosis.
  • Left eye is unable to move upwards, downwards, or inwards towards the nose, indicating a lack of adduction, elevation, and depression.

 

Signs observed in a patient with oculomotor nerve palsy include:

 

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position (“down and out”) due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Normal abduction due to the intact lateral rectus.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial rectus palsy: Incorrect because. Medial rectus palsy specifically affects the ability of the eye to adduct (move inward toward the nose). If only the medial rectus were paretic, you would primarily observe limitation in horizontal inward movement of the affected eye without the associated ptosis, "down and out" positioning, or pupil involvement seen in the provided images. These broader symptoms indicate involvement of multiple muscles, which is characteristic of oculomotor nerve palsy, not isolated medial rectus palsy.

 

Option B. Trochlear nerve palsy: Incorrect because. Trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) palsy affects the superior oblique muscle, which primarily results in problems with eye rotation and vertical gaze, especially when looking downward and inward. Patients often present with vertical diplopia (double vision), head tilt away from the side of the lesion to compensate for the misalignment, and no ptosis or pupillary involvement. The symptoms and the eye movement limitations shown in the images do not match those typically associated with trochlear nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve palsy: Incorrect because. Abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) palsy results in failure of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to an inability to abduct the eye (move outward). Patients with this condition will have the affected eye positioned inward (medially) due to unopposed action of the medial rectus. This condition would not cause the ptosis or the "down and out" appearance nor the wide range of motion impairments displayed in the images, such as the inability to move the eye upward or downward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculomotor nerve palsy significantly affects eye movement and eyelid function due to its role in innervating most of the extraocular muscles as well as lifting the eyelid. Diagnosis often involves a comprehensive evaluation of eye movement patterns, eyelid function, and pupil response, along with investigations to determine underlying causes. Treatment focuses on addressing the root cause and managing symptoms to protect eye function and quality of life.

questions.text: A child with a low socio-economic background presents with white spots in both the eyes in the temporal conjunctiva. On examination, conjunctival xerosis is also noted. Which of the following vitamins could be deficient in this child?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

The description given in the question is that of Bitot spots seen in vitamin A deficiency.

 

BITOT SPOT:

 

  • Xerosis of conjunctiva
  • Raised, silvery white
  • Foamy triangular patch
  • Usually bilateral & temporal
  • Sign of Vitamin A deficiency

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Deficiency in Vitamin D primarily leads to rickets in children, which affects bone development and growth. It does not cause Bitot’s spots or conjunctival xerosis.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Deficiency in Vitamin E can lead to neurological problems and hemolytic anemia but does not affect the conjunctiva or cause the signs described in the question.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Deficiency in Vitamin B12 primarily affects the hematological and nervous systems, causing conditions such as megaloblastic anemia and neuropathy. It does not cause conjunctival xerosis or Bitot’s spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Treatment Guidelines

 

Vitamin A therapy

questions.text: Which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most likely to be observed in a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2020
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Marcus Gunn pupil  

 

  • Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nerve damage.
  • A defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye can cause a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test.
  • The Marcus Gunn pupil is observed when the flashlight is moved from the normal to the abnormal eye and the affected pupil dilates instead of remaining constricted.
  • Seen in optic neuritis.
  • Earliest indictor of optic nerve disease (Retrobulbar neuritis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adie tonic pupil is a Sluggishly reacting mid-dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

 

Option C. Argyll-Robertson pupils (AR pupils) are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation, which is a specific sign in neurosyphilis and is due to a lesion in the pretectal nucleus.

 

Option D. Hutchinson's pupil is a clinical sign where the pupil on the side of an intracranial mass lesion is dilated and unreactive to light, due to compression of the oculomotor nerve on that side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marcus Gunn pupil, or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), is an important clinical sign in primary open-angle glaucoma, indicating asymmetric optic nerve damage, and is identified using the swinging flashlight test.

choices.text: Pupil dilation with 11 cis retinol combining with scotopsin
Pupil dilation with 11 cis retinoid combining with scotopsin
Pupil dilation with all cis retinol combining with scotopsin
Pupil dilation with all cis retinoid combining with scotopsin

questions.text: When a person enters a movie with dim light, which of the following changes will occur? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pupil dilation with 11 cis retinol combining with scotopsin

 

When a person moves from a well-lit environment to a dimly lit one, such as entering a movie theatre, several physiological changes occur in the eye to adapt to the lower light levels. These changes include pupil dilation and biochemical processes in the retina.

 

Key Processes in Dim Light Adaptation:

 

  • Pupil dilation: The pupils enlarge to allow more light to enter the eye, enhancing visibility in low-light conditions.
  • Rhodopsin Regeneration: In the dim light, 11-cis retinol (a form of vitamin A) combines with the protein scotopsin to form rhodopsin. Rhodopsin is a light-sensitive receptor protein found in the rod cells of the retina. When exposed to light, rhodopsin breaks down into all-trans retinal and opsin, initiating a signal transduction pathway that ultimately results in visual perception.

 

The visual cycle is shown in the following diagram-

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pupil dilation with 11-cis retinoid combining with scotopsin: This option is incorrect because "retinoid" is a more general term that includes various forms of vitamin A derivatives. The specific form involved in the visual cycle is 11-cis retinol.

 

Option C. Pupil dilation with all-cis retinol combining with scotopsin: This is incorrect because the active form involved in the regeneration of rhodopsin is 11-cis retinol, not all-cis retinol.

 

Option D. Pupil dilation with all-cis retinoid combining with scotopsin: This is incorrect for the same reason as option B. The specific form involved is 11-cis retinol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In low-light conditions, such as entering a dimly lit movie theatre, the pupils dilate to allow more light into the eye, and 11-cis retinal combines with scotopsin to form rhodopsin, which is crucial for night vision.

questions.text: A patient underwent LASIK for myopia and now is undergoing cataract surgery. What is the formula used for lens power calculation in this patient?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haigis-L  

 

  • The Haigis-L regression formula is used for lens power calculation in patients undergoing cataract surgery with a past history of LASIK for myopia.
  • Corneal refractive surgery significantly affects the IOL power required, making standard IOL calculations unsuitable.
  • Several methods of calculating corneal refractive power are used, such as the double-K method, Masket and modified Masket, and Haigis-L formulas.
  • The Haigis-L regression formula uses statistical data to facilitate calculation on post-refractive surgery eyes using only standard inputs.
  • It may be prudent to utilize more than one method of IOL calculation.

 

NEWER IOL POWER CALCULATION FORMULAE FOR POST REFRACTIVE SURGERY PATIENTS ARE –

 

  • Wang-Koch-Maloney
  • Shammas
  • Haigis-L
  • Galilei
  • Potvin-Hill Pentacam
  • Barrett True K No History      

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SRK 1 and Option B. SRK 2: These are older formulas that do not account for post-refractive surgery changes in corneal curvature and are less accurate in such cases.

 

Option C. Hoffer Q: While useful for eyes with shorter axial lengths, this formula also does not specifically adjust for the changes induced by corneal refractive surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients who have had previous corneal refractive surgery like LASIK, specialized IOL calculation formulas such as Haigis-L should be used to ensure accurate lens power calculation for cataract surgery. This formula specifically addresses the altered corneal parameters to provide a more precise refractive outcome.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the treatment of amblyopia? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Video games

 

  • Video games are not a recognized treatment for amblyopia. Amblyopia treatment focuses on forcing use of the amblyopic eye and correcting underlying causes. The established treatments include occlusion therapy (the mainstay treatment where the normal eye is patched), full refractive error correction as the primary step, and strabismus surgery when squint is the underlying cause. 
  • The treatment modalities follow the "4 O's" principle: Optical correction, Occlusion therapy, Orthoptic exercises, and Operation for squint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Strabismus Surgery: This is correct as a treatment option. For strabismic amblyopia, the sources clearly state treatment needs "4 'O': Optical correction of Refractive error, Occlusion Therapy, Orthoptic Exercises, Operation for squint." Surgery addresses the underlying strabismus that causes amblyopia.

 

Option C. Occlusion by patching: This is correct and represents the gold standard treatment. The sources emphasize "Occlusion therapy is the best treatment/treatment of choice till date." The conventional schedule involves occluding the normal eye for days equal to the child's age in years, forcing use of the amblyopic eye.

 

Option D. Refractive error correction: This is correct as a fundamental treatment step. The sources state that for anisometropic and ametropic amblyopia, treatment should begin with "full correction of Refractive error." This must be done before starting occlusion therapy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Standard amblyopia treatment follows the systematic approach of refractive correction, occlusion therapy, orthoptic exercises, and surgical correction of underlying strabismus - general video games are not part of established amblyopia treatment protocols.

 

TYPES OF AMBLYOPIA – 

 

A. Refractive Amblyopia:

 

  • This is the most common type
  • Caused by significant differences in refractive errors (like near   sightedness, farsightedness, or astigmatism) between the two eyes.

 

B. Strabismic Amblyopia: 

 

  • 5Develops due to eye misalignment – SQUINT.

 

C. Stimulus Deprivation Amblyopia:

 

  • Occurs when something physically blocks or impairs the visual input to one eye.
  • Examples include cataracts, corneal opacities, or ptosis.

questions.text: What is the normal arteriovenous ratio at the optic disc? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2:3

 

Explanation: 


The normal arteriovenous (AV) ratio at the optic disc is 2:3. This ratio represents the normal relationship between arteriole and venule caliber at the optic disc. The artery appears lighter in color and has a thicker wall, while the vein appears darker and has a thinner wall. This ratio is important in assessing various ocular conditions, particularly hypertensive retinopathy.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. 2:5: This is incorrect as it suggests arterioles are too narrow compared to venules. This ratio would indicate pathological narrowing of arterioles.

 

Option C. 1:5: This is incorrect and would represent a severely abnormal ratio suggesting significant arteriolar narrowing, which might be seen in advanced hypertensive retinopathy.

 

Option D. 1:3: While this ratio is seen in hypertensive retinopathy, it is not the normal AV ratio. In hypertensive retinopathy, there is narrowing of arterioles leading to a reduction in the AV ratio from 2:3 to 1:3.

 

Educational Objective: 


The normal arteriovenous ratio at the optic disc is 2:3, which serves as a baseline for evaluating vascular changes in various retinal conditions, particularly hypertensive retinopathy.

questions.text: The most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19 is: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

  • COVID-19 can cause ocular manifestations due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors on the cornea and conjunctiva, which are potential target tissues for SARS-CoV-2.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal vein thrombosis: While COVID-19 can cause thrombotic complications, retinal vein thrombosis is not commonly reported as a primary ocular manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Viral keratouveitis: There is limited evidence to suggest that COVID-19 directly causes viral keratouveitis. This condition involves inflammation of the cornea and uvea and is more commonly associated with other viruses.
