Option D. Pseudomembranous conjunctivitis: Pseudomembranes in the context of conjunctivitis are not true membranes but rather a buildup of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and mucus. They can adhere to the conjunctival tissue and may cause a gritty or painful sensation in the eye. Some common causes of pseudomembranous conjunctivitis include:
 

  1. Bacterial Infections: Bacterial conjunctivitis, particularly caused by certain strains of bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae or Streptococcus pneumoniae, can lead to the formation of pseudomembranes.
  2. Viral Infections: In rare cases, certain viruses, such as adenoviruses, can cause pseudomembranous conjunctivitis.
  3. Allergic Reactions: Severe allergic conjunctivitis can lead to the development of pseudomembranes, although this is less common.

 

Treatment for pseudomembranous conjunctivitis typically involves addressing the underlying cause, which may include antibiotics for bacterial infections or antiviral medications for viral infections. In some cases, topical steroids may be prescribed to reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation seen in patients with COVID-19, highlighting the virus's ability to affect multiple body systems including the eyes. This underscores the importance of protective measures for healthcare providers, such as wearing masks and eye protection when examining patients suspected of having COVID-19.

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

 

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: 
    1. The power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere),
    2. The power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder),
    3. The axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

 

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not. In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens. The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC). The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.

 

Types of astigmatism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. +1.00 DS: This represents a convex spherical lens for hypermetropia (farsightedness) and is not used for astigmatism correction.

 

Option C. -1.00 DS: This represents a concave spherical lens for simple myopia (nearsightedness) but does not correct astigmatism.

 

Option D. -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree: This represents a prescription for compound myopic astigmatism, where both meridians are myopic, one corrected by the spherical component and the other by the cylindrical component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction with a cylindrical lens that corrects the myopic meridian, typically specified with the cylinder power and the axis. The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism in this case is -1.00 DC X 180 degrees.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child’s father brought him for checkup. On examination, there was white pupillary reflex. USG findings shows intraocular mass with calcification in the eye. There is a family history of enucleation. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retinoblastoma

 

Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina that typically presents in young children. It often presents with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) and may be associated with an intraocular mass with calcification. There is also a familial predisposition to retinoblastoma, which is indicated by the family history of enucleation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exudative retinal detachment: Exudative retinal detachment is a condition where fluid accumulates under the retina, leading to detachment. It is not typically associated with a white pupillary reflex or intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Option B. Pediatric tuberculosis: Pediatric tuberculosis can affect various organs, including the eyes, but it usually presents with other signs and symptoms such as fever, cough, and weight loss. It is unlikely to present with a white pupillary reflex and intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Option C. Retinopathy of prematurity: Retinopathy of prematurity is a condition affecting premature infants and is characterized by abnormal blood vessel growth in the retina. It does not typically present with a white pupillary reflex or intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma should be considered in a young child with a white pupillary reflex and intraocular mass with calcification, especially in the presence of a family history of enucleation.

questions.text: Which investigation is best used to visualize the inner layers of the retina in vivo? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Optical Coherence Tomography

 

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) is the gold standard investigation for visualizing all layers of the retina in vivo. OCT is a light-based, non-invasive imaging technique that provides high-resolution cross-sectional images of the retina. It can clearly demonstrate all 10 layers of the retina, from the internal limiting membrane to the retinal pigment epithelium, and even visualize the choroid beneath. The images can be displayed in grayscale or color-coded format. Since OCT uses light and not radiation, it can be repeated as frequently as required without any risk to the patient, making it ideal for monitoring retinal conditions over time.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA): This investigation is primarily used to assess retinal vasculature and blood flow patterns. FFA involves injecting fluorescein dye intravenously, which binds to proteins and stays within blood vessels. It helps identify leaking areas, neovascularization, and capillary non-perfusion areas, particularly useful in diabetic retinopathy. However, it does not visualize the individual layers of the retina.

 

 

 

Option B. USG B scan: B-scan ultrasonography is a two-dimensional ultrasound used primarily when the media is opaque (such as in dense cataracts or vitreous hemorrhage) and ophthalmoscopy cannot be performed. While it provides information about the integrity of the posterior segment and can detect retinal detachment or masses, it cannot visualize the individual retinal layers due to its lower resolution compared to OCT.

 

 

Option C. Ophthalmoscope: Ophthalmoscopy (both direct and indirect) provides a view of the fundus, allowing visualization of the optic nerve, retinal vessels, and retinal surface. It can detect hemorrhages, exudates, and other surface abnormalities but cannot differentiate between the individual layers of the retina. It only shows the surface appearance of the retina, not its internal structure.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCT is the only investigation that can visualize all 10 individual layers of the retina in vivo using light-based technology without radiation exposure.

 

Comparison of Retinal Imaging Modalities

choices.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescein dye

questions.text: What is the characteristic feature of a fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Satellite lesion

 

Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer.

 

The signs of a fungal ulcer include:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer.
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.
  • Perforation in mycotic ulcer is rare but can occur.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reverse hypopyon:  "Reverse hypopyon" can form when emulsified silicone oil used during vitreoretinal surgery enters the anterior chamber of the eye. The silicone oil floats in the aqueous to look like a layered hypopyon in the upper portion of the anterior chamber. Silicone Oil in anterior chamber is called hyperoleon.

 

 

Inverted or reverse hypopyon as a result of emulsification into the anterior chamber. Migration of silicon oil into the anterior chamber displaces aqueous inferiorly and results in a density gradient demarcation line.

 

Option B. Dendritic ulcer on fluorescein dye: Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

 

Pseudodendritic ulcer is caused by acanthamoeba.

 

Option C. Ring abscess: Can be seen in recurrent stromal herpes keratitis or acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Satellite lesions around the main ulcer are characteristic of fungal corneal ulcers, along with irregular margins, immune rings, and potentially immobile hypopyon.

questions.text: Which syndrome is characterized by the symmetrical enlargement of both lacrimal and salivary glands? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mikulicz's Syndrome

 

Mikulicz's Syndrome is specifically characterized by bilaterally symmetrical enlargement of the lacrimal and salivary glands. This condition is associated with various systemic diseases including leukemias, lymphosarcomas, benign lymphoid hyperplasia, Hodgkin's disease, sarcoidosis, and tuberculosis. This distinct pattern of bilateral glandular enlargement is the hallmark feature that defines this syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sjögren's Syndrome: While Sjögren's syndrome does affect both lacrimal and salivary glands, it presents primarily as an autoimmune chronic inflammatory disease characterized by aqueous deficiency dry eye (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and xerostomia (dryness of mouth), not symmetrical glandular enlargement. It typically occurs in women between 40-50 years of age.

 

Option C. Sturge-Weber Syndrome: This is associated with nevus flammeus (port wine stain), not lacrimal or salivary gland enlargement. It's characterized by facial vascular malformation.

 

Option D. Vogt-Koyanagi Syndrome: This is associated with poliosis (greying of eyelashes and eyebrows) and various ocular conditions, not with lacrimal or salivary gland enlargement.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mikulicz's Syndrome presents with bilateral symmetrical enlargement of both lacrimal and salivary glands and should prompt investigation for underlying systemic conditions like lymphoproliferative disorders, sarcoidosis, or tuberculosis.

questions.text: In Horner syndrome, ptosis is seen. In this condition, which muscle is implicated? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muller's muscle

 

 

Horner syndrome is a condition resulting from a lesion in the sympathetic pathway. It is characterized by a classical triad of symptoms:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) - Mild

 

Miosis (constricted pupil)

 

Anhidrosis (lack of sweating on the affected side of the face).

 

In this condition, ptosis occurs due to the involvement of the Muller's muscle, which is a small muscle in the upper eyelid that is innervated by the sympathetic nervous system. The Muller's muscle is responsible for approximately 2 mm of eyelid elevation. When this muscle is affected, it leads to mild ptosis, which is a hallmark sign of Horner syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LPS muscle: The Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS) muscle is responsible for the major elevation of the upper eyelid and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), not the sympathetic system. It is not implicated in Horner syndrome.

 

Option B. Orbicularis Oculi: This muscle is responsible for closing the eyelids and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). It plays no role in eyelid elevation and is not involved in Horner syndrome.

 

Option D. Horner muscle: There is no muscle known as the "Horner muscle." This is not a correct anatomical term and does not pertain to Horner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mild ptosis seen in Horner syndrome is due to the involvement of the Muller's muscle, which has sympathetic innervation and contributes to a small degree of eyelid elevation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with redness and pain in the eye. Examination revealed an IOP of 38 mm of Hg, aqueous flare, and corneal precipitates. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in her? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prostaglandin analogs

 

  • The clinical vignette suggests anterior uveitis with a raised intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues like latanoprost increase uveoscleral outflow and lower intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues act by stimulating prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases that increase uveoscleral outflow.
  • Prostaglandin analogues should be used with caution in patients with uveitis, iritis, cystoid macular edema, and herpes simplex keratitis.
  • Prostaglandin analogues are the least suited for use in this patient as they can worsen the anterior uveitis.
  • PG Analogues can also cause cystoids macular edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: These are generally safe in uveitis unless contraindicated for systemic reasons.

 

Option B. Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic can be used for quick reduction of IOP in acute settings but does not exacerbate uveitis.

 

Option C. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: Also safe for use in reducing IOP in uveitis, unless systemic contraindications exist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with anterior uveitis and high IOP, prostaglandin analogs should be avoided due to their potential to worsen intraocular inflammation and the risk of inducing or exacerbating cystoid macular edema. Other options such as beta blockers, mannitol, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors can be considered based on the individual patient's overall health and specific eye condition.

questions.text: The type of cataract associated with blunt trauma is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rosette cataract

 

Rosette cataract is a type of cataract typically associated with blunt trauma to the eye. This type of cataract has a characteristic flower-like appearance, resembling the petals of a rose, hence the name "rosette." Blunt trauma can cause disruption in the lens fibers, leading to the formation of this unique pattern, which can be located either in the anterior or posterior cortex of the lens.

 

 

Vossius ring:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sunflower cataract: Sunflower cataract is seen in patients with Wilson's disease, a disorder of copper metabolism. It is not associated with trauma.

 

 

Option B. Snowflake cataract: Snowflake cataract is typically seen in diabetic patients and is characterized by the presence of multiple small, white opacities in the lens. It is not related to blunt trauma.

 

 

Option D. Christmas tree cataract: Christmas tree cataract is seen in patients with myotonic dystrophy. It presents with brightly colored, polychromatic crystals within the lens, which resemble the decorations on a Christmas tree. This type of cataract is not associated with trauma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rosette cataract is the type of cataract that develops following blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by its distinctive flower-like pattern.
